title: Miss E... So Addictive
text:
Miss E... So Addictive is the third <a href="studio%20album">studio album</a> by American rapper <a href="Missy%20Elliott">Missy Elliott</a>. The album spawned the club and R&B/hip-hop hits "<a href="One%20Minute%20Man">One Minute Man</a>", featuring Ludacris and Trina, and "<a href="Get%20Ur%20Freak%20On">Get Ur Freak On</a>", as well as the international club hit "<a href="4%20My%20People">4 My People</a>" and the less commercially successful single "<a href="Take%20Away%20%28song%29">Take Away</a>".
The album debuted at number two on the US <a href="Billboard%20200">"Billboard" 200</a> chart, selling 405,000 copies in its first week. The album was certified <a href="RIAA%20Certification">platinum</a> by the <a href="Recording%20Industry%20Association%20of%20America">Recording Industry Association of America</a> (RIAA). The album garnered two Grammy Awards for "<a href="Get%20Ur%20Freak%20On">Get Ur Freak On</a>" and the non-single "Scream a.k.a. Itchin'" for <a href="Best%20Rap%20Solo%20Performance">Best Rap Solo Performance</a> and <a href="Best%20Female%20Rap%20Solo%20Performance">Best Female Rap Solo Performance</a> respectively.
Critical reception.
"Miss E... So Addictive" received widespread acclaim from music critics. On <a href="Metacritic">Metacritic</a>, the album holds a score of 89 out of 100 based on 16 reviews, indicating "universal acclaim." The album is also ranked 70th on the site's list of best-reviewed albums. "<a href="Q%20magazine">Q</a>" listed the album as one of the best 50 albums of 2001. John Bush from <a href="AllMusic">AllMusic</a> felt that Elliott was "sounding more assured of her various strengths than at any time since her startling debut" and called "her best album so far." He wrote that it's "a tribute to her incredible songwriting skills and Timbaland's continuing production excellence that she can have it any way she wants it and still come away with a full-length that hangs together brilliantly."
Commercial performance.
"Miss E... So Addictive" debuted at number two on the US <a href="Billboard%20200">"Billboard" 200</a> chart, selling 250,000 copies in its first week. This became Elliott's third US top ten debut. The album ended up spending a total of 43 weeks on the chart. On July 18, 2001, the album was certified <a href="RIAA%20Certification">platinum</a> by the <a href="Recording%20Industry%20Association%20of%20America">Recording Industry Association of America</a> (RIAA) for sales of over a million copies in the United States. As of November 2015, the album has sold 1,767,000 copies in the US.
Track listing.
Credits adapted from the album's liner notes.
